entry.title: Why your speedometer is lying to you (in a good way)
entry.content:
Why your speedometer is lying to you (in a good way)

If you‚Äôve ever connected an OBD scanner to your car and watched its speed readout, you may have noticed something odd: your dashboard doesn‚Äôt match the scanner‚Äôs speed. Your speedometer might say 70 mph while the OBD data shows 67. Which one‚Äôs the truth?

Well, turns out the answer‚Äôs a bit more complicated than you might expect, and I lost myself down a rabbit hole of worldwide automotive regulations tonight to get to the bottom of it.

#

The legal framework

In most of the world, vehicle speedometers are legally required to never display a speed that is lower than your actual speed.

The reasoning boils down to this: if your speedometer shows a number that is too low, you might break the speed limit while believing you‚Äôre driving legally.

And nobody wants a ticket for going 72 in a 70 zone when their dashboard clearly showed 70.

From the European standard, UNECE Regulation 39, Section 5.4:

The speed indicated shall not be less than the true speed of the vehicle. At the test speeds specified in paragraph 5.3.5. above, there shall be the following relationship between the speed displayed (V1) and the true speed (V2).

0 ‚â§ (V1 - V2) ‚â§ 0.1 V2 + 4 km/h

If we rewrite the standard‚Äôs formula in terms of the displayed speed:

Vactual ‚â§ Vdisplayed ‚â§ 1.1 √ó Vactual + 4 km/h

This creates two rules:

  1. The displayed speed can never be below your actual speed.

  2. The displayed speed can be up to 110% above your true speed, plus 4 km/h.

A concrete example: if you‚Äôre actually traveling at 100 km/h (about 62 mph), your speedometer could legally display anywhere from 100 to 114 km/h (62 to 71 mph), but never 99 km/h. That‚Äôs a potential 14 km/h (9 mph) buffer at highway speeds.

#

Who follows this regulation?

Image from Wikipedia‚Äôs ‚ÄúWorld Forum for Harmonization of Vehicle Regulations‚Äù

UNECE Regulation 39 is part of the 1958 Agreement on vehicle technical harmonization. As of 2023, there are 68 contracting parties, including:

  • The European Union and all its member states

  • United Kingdom, Norway, Switzerland, Andorra, San Marino

  • Russia, Ukraine, Belarus, Turkey, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Armenia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan

  • Japan, South Korea, Thailand, Malaysia, Vietnam, Philippines, Pakistan

  • Australia, New Zealand

  • South Africa, Egypt, Tunisia, Nigeria, Uganda

Australia explicitly adopts UNECE R39 through ADR 18/03 for vehicles manufactured after July 2007.

Notable exceptions: The United States and Canada are not signatories to the 1958 Agreement. The US has its own Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards (FMVSS), and Canada‚Äôs Transport Canada does not regulate speedometer accuracy at the federal level.

#

Why this is good for you

When you glance at your speedometer and see a higher number, you instinctively ease off the gas. That‚Äôs the point. The inflated reading encourages you to drive a bit slower than you otherwise might, creating a real-world safety margin without you having to think about it.

It also protects you from the small, unconscious speed creep that happens on long drives. A momentary lapse in attention won‚Äôt push you over the limit because there‚Äôs already a buffer built in. Yes, the speedometer is lying to you, but it‚Äôs a lie that complements driver tendencies to reduce tickets and improve road safety.

#

How tire wear impacts your speedometer

Tire wear actually reinforces this buffer over time. As your tires wear down, their diameter shrinks, which means the wheels have to rotate more times to cover the same distance. Since your car‚Äôs speed sensors count wheel rotations, worn tires cause both the dashboard and OBD to read higher than your true ground speed. GPS, which measures your actual position via satellite, isn‚Äôt affected by tire size.

Manufacturers account for this by calibrating toward the edge of the legal tolerance when the car is new, knowing the safety margin will grow as the tires wear.

#

The takeaway

When you use OBD or GPS to determine your car‚Äôs speed, you‚Äôll often get a value that doesn‚Äôt match what‚Äôs shown on your car‚Äôs speedometer. This is working as intended, and you should prefer your car‚Äôs speedometer over an OBD or GPS speedometer while driving. After the drive, you can use direct OBD readings from an app like Sidecar to better understand your ‚Äútrue‚Äù trip details.

Drive safe,

‚Äì Jeff

entry.title: Sidecar trip report: Halloween edition
entry.content:
Sidecar trip report: Halloween edition

Sidecar‚Äôs biggest release yet is here, and it‚Äôs a spoooooky one! üëª

A lot landed in this Sidecar release. But first off: a huge thank you to the entire Sidecar beta testing community and everyone who has provided feedback along the way. If you aren‚Äôt already signed up for the newsletter, you can join the beta crew here.

#

October 2025 release notes

Here‚Äôs a quick overview of everything that launched today:

  • Navigation instructions on the phone
  • Volvo Connected Accounts
  • Pinnable locations
  • Custom place labels (Home/Work)
  • Intelligent Quick Destinations
  • Personalized search engine
  • iCloud backup status
  • Improved onboarding notifications
  • Photos in the place sheet
  • PID Detector can now scan 11-bit CAN networks
  • Spooky holiday decorations

#

Navigation instructions on the phone

iPhone navigators, this one‚Äôs for you!

One of the side-effects of building the new navigation widgets is that the widgets can now be used on the phone, too! This works even without a Sidecar+ subscription and is a big improvement to the baseline navigation experience for those using a mounted phone.

The navigation widgets can be used in landscape mode on the phone as well, though there‚Äôs a few rough edges there that still need to be ironed out.

#

Volvo Connected Accounts

Volvo drivers can now log in to Sidecar!

Many thanks to the Sidecar Volvo beta drivers who provided feedback and bug reports as we got this built out. This is hot off the press, so please continue emailing bugs to support@clutch.engineering.

Volvo connected accounts allow you to check in on the state of your vehicle without being in the car and lock your car using Sidecar‚Äôs widgets and Shortcuts. Add your account in Settings > Vehicles & accounts.

Volvo Connected accounts are a Sidecar+ benefit.

#

Pinnable locations

You can finally pin your favorite destinations on the map üòÑ

Whether it‚Äôs home, work, or your favorite haunts üëª Sidecar can now be your personal address book. All pins stay local on your device and can be backed up to iCloud through your Journeys database.

To pin locations, open the place sheet and tap the pin button in the bottom corner. You can also drop a pin anywhere and pin it with a long-tap on the map.

#

Custom place labels

Tired of typing your home address to get home all the time? Me too! You can now rename locations and pins so that you can find them more easily. We call our local pharmacy ‚ÄúFrog world‚Äù, which is a much more fun way to load up directions üòÑ

To rename a location, open its place sheet and tap the three-dot menu button in the bottom corner. If you want to see the custom name on the map you‚Äôll have to pin the location.

#

Intelligent Quick Destinations

Sidecar+ subscribers using trip logging now have a dramatically improved Quick Destinations algorithm that fuses your favorite places with your weekly routines. Your entire trip logging history is provided to Sidecar‚Äôs on-device intelligence to provide uncannily accurate suggestions that are just a tap away in CarPlay.

It‚Äôs a really cool experience to hop in the car and see suggestions for exactly where you want to go.

#

Personalized search engine

The Sidecar search engine is now personalized based on your pinned locations, weekly patterns, and travel times. Sidecar‚Äôs on-device intelligence gets smarter the more you drive with Sidecar (especially with Sidecar+).

#

iCloud backup status

Keep an eye on your iCloud backups with the new progress indicator. You can tap it to collapse it if it‚Äôs getting in the way üòÑ

#

Improved onboarding notifications

Over the past few weeks we‚Äôve been trialing a new automatic-onboarding process that may have caused you to get more onboarding notifications than you would have preferred. In this new release, you‚Äôll now only get notifications when new parameters are available, and if you tap the notification you can get a preview of exactly which parameters were added to your vehicle.

#

Photos in the place sheet

Place sheets now include photography from the location if available! You can tap a photo to view it in full-screen.

#

PID Detector can now scan 11-bit CAN networks

A new PID Detector strategy is now available for scanning 11-bit CAN networks. Please use this feature with care and caution!

#

Spooky holiday decorations

Make sure to turn on Sidecar‚Äôs holiday decorations in the Settings tab üëª

Phew, that was a huge release. Hope you enjoy the new features and improvements to Sidecar; onto the next one and as Monomeeth always says,

‚ÄúHappy Sidecar‚Äôing.‚Äù

‚Äì Jeff
